definition: Annual compliance testing and audit program to assess institution-wide GLBA compliance. Includes risk assessment audit plan development
version: Per GLBA Safeguards Rule Element 4 (16 CFR 314.4(d)) and Privacy Rule, institutions must implement written comprehensive information security program with testing and monitoring designed to evaluate the effectiveness of safeguards. Audit and testing program is fundamental control; required to verify safeguard adequacy; identifies control deficiencies; informs remediation efforts. Audit program components: annual audit plan development; audit risk assessment; control testing procedures; technical testing (vulnerability scans, penetration testing); compliance testing (policy compliance, exception documentation); findings documentation; management response and remediation tracking; board reporting. Testing frequency: annual minimum for safeguards; quarterly or continuous for high-risk areas; testing following major system changes; testing after incidents; ongoing monitoring; continuous assessment.
status: All financial institutions; required for all institution sizes; applies to all safeguard elements; applies to all locations and business units; applies to all data types and systems
key_features: Internal Audit Director for audit program; Compliance Officer for coordination; IT Security for technical testing; Chief Risk Officer for audit oversight; Board Audit Committee for reporting; External auditors for independent verification

column12: Mandatory control; annual audit minimum required; subject to examination focus; examination will evaluate audit effectiveness; poor audit results require remediation; audit quality directly affects compliance posture
column13: Annual Audit Plan Development: Step 1 - Risk Assessment: evaluate all safeguard elements (administrative, technical, physical); identify highest-risk areas; assess prior findings; assess recent changes; assess incident history; assess regulatory feedback; prioritize testing areas. Step 2 - Audit Scope Definition: determine scope (institution-wide or segmented); identify systems to test; identify controls to test; identify data access to review; determine testing depth and breadth. Step 3 - Audit Procedures Development: develop detailed testing procedures; specific controls to test; specific tests to perform; expected outcomes; test documentation requirements. Step 4 - Resource Allocation: determine staff needed; identify skills required; external resources needed; budget allocation; timeline development. Step 5 - Plan Approval: audit plan reviewed by Compliance Officer, CRO, and Board Audit Committee; documented; communicated to relevant departments; approval documented. Annual Audit Topics: Administrative Safeguards: information security program structure; oversight and responsibility assignment; incident response plan existence; business continuity planning; testing procedures; personnel security; access controls. Technical Safeguards: encryption implementation; system access controls; authentication and authorization; data transmission security; monitoring and detecting unauthorized access; vulnerability management; patch management. Physical Safeguards: facility controls; access to facilities; surveillance systems; environmental controls; media storage and disposal; equipment inventory; maintenance logs. Privacy Rule Compliance: privacy notice accuracy and completeness; privacy notice delivery methods; opt-out procedures; implementation; consumer request handling; information sharing practices; employee training on privacy obligations. Pretexting Prevention: identification procedures; staff training on pretexting; monitoring for pretexting; response procedures; vendor certification. Incident Response: incident response plan adequacy; incident detection procedures; response procedures; notification procedures; testing of procedures. Business Continuity: plan existence and adequacy; critical function identification; backup procedures; recovery procedures; testing frequency; alternative processing availability. Third-Party Management: vendor assessment adequacy; vendor contracts GLBA-compliant; vendor monitoring; incident reporting. Control Testing Procedures: Administrative Controls Testing: interview relevant staff; review policies and procedures; assess compliance with procedures; test access control processes; test incident response procedures; review documentation. Technical Controls Testing: vulnerability scanning (network and application scanning); penetration testing (attempt to gain unauthorized access); access control testing (verify access restrictions); encryption verification (verify encryption implementation); log review (assess audit trail adequacy); patch assessment (verify timely patching); configuration review. Physical Controls Testing: inspect facilities; verify access controls; test surveillance systems; review environmental controls; assess media storage; inspect disposal procedures; equipment inventory verification. Compliance Testing: review sample of privacy notices; verify opt-out implementation; test consumer request handling; sample check employee compliance; review vendor agreements; assess incident response; test training completion. Testing Documentation: tests documented with: procedure description; date of test; tester identification; systems/controls tested; test results; exceptions noted; findings identified. Findings Classification: Rating system for findings: Critical (immediate remediation required, material deficiency, regulatory risk); High (significant deficiency, should remediate within 30 days); Medium (control improvement opportunity, remediate within 60 days); Low (enhancement recommendation, consider for future implementation). Finding Documentation: each finding documented with: control assessed; finding description; risk assessment; root cause; remediation recommendation; responsible party; timeline for remediation; interim controls if applicable. Management Response: management responds to findings with: agreement or disagreement; remediation plan if agreed; timeline for implementation; resource allocation; interim measures if needed. Remediation Tracking: monitor remediation progress; verify completion; retesting of controls after remediation; closure documentation; assessment of remediation effectiveness; trending of findings. Technical Testing Procedures: Vulnerability Scanning: scan network and systems for known vulnerabilities; automated scanning tools; internal scans; external scans (from outside network); quarterly minimum scanning recommended. Penetration Testing: ethical hacking attempts; attempt to gain unauthorized system access; test control effectiveness; identify exploitable vulnerabilities; annual penetration testing recommended. Patch Assessment: review patch management procedures; verify timely patching; test for unpatched systems; assess backlog of patches; evaluate patch testing procedures. Access Control Testing: sample of users and verify appropriate access; verify access restriction enforcement; test removal of access; test privilege access management; assess segregation of duties. Encryption Verification: verify encryption in transit (SSL/TLS for web services, VPN for remote access); verify encryption at rest; test encryption functionality; assess key management; verify encryption standards compliance. Log Review: review system and application logs; assess audit trail adequacy; verify logging of sensitive events; assess log retention; assess log protection. Continuous Monitoring: implement automated monitoring for: unauthorized access attempts; privilege access usage; data exfiltration attempts; malware detection; system vulnerabilities; configuration changes. Board Reporting: annual audit results reported to Board or Audit Committee; key findings presented; remediation status; risk assessment; trends identified; recommendations. Report Content: summary of audit scope and procedures; findings and risk classification; remediation status; management responses; trends from prior years; recommendations; conclusion on overall compliance posture. Examination Preparation: maintain audit documentation; organize by control area; prepare sample files for examiner review; be able to explain audit procedures; demonstrate testing effectiveness; evidence of findings remediation; audit program effectiveness. External Audit Coordination: external auditors may perform agreed-upon procedures; coordination with external audit; sharing of testing results; assessment of control environment; external audit opinion on controls. Common Audit Findings: insufficient audit scope; inadequate testing depth; inadequate documentation; failures to remediate prior findings; weak vendor management; insufficient incident response testing; gaps in training. Continuous Improvement: audit program refined based on results; testing procedures enhanced; resource adjustments; emerging risk assessment; regulatory changes considered; best practices incorporated.

definition: Preparation for federal regulatory examination of GLBA compliance including documentation organization
version: Per GLBA Section 505 and examination authority of regulators (FTC, Federal Reserve, OCC, FDIC, NCUA, CFPB), financial institutions are subject to regular examination for GLBA compliance. Examination preparation is critical; requires organized documentation; clear understanding of requirements; communication plan. Examination process: examiner notification; examination scope determination; document request; on-site examination; interview of staff; testing of controls; findings communication; remediation planning. Examination objectives: verify GLBA compliance; assess information security program; test safeguards; evaluate incident response; assess business continuity; evaluate vendor management; assess training and awareness; identify deficiencies; recommend improvements.
status: All financial institutions subject to GLBA examination; all regulated institutions; applies to all locations; applies to all business units; scope depends on institution size and prior findings
key_features: Chief Compliance Officer for examination coordination; Chief Information Security Officer for security testing; Chief Risk Officer for risk assessment; General Counsel for legal issues; Board for findings and remediation planning; Department heads for specific area testing
column11: GLBA Section 505 (15 USC 6805) examination authority; Regulator-specific examination procedures; FTC examination manual; Federal Reserve examination guidance; OCC examination guidance; FDIC examination guidance; NCUA examination guidance; Examination procedures vary by regulator
column12: Mandatory requirement; examination occurs regularly (every 1-3 years depending on size and prior findings); examination findings directly affect compliance assessment; enforcement actions possible if significant deficiencies; examination schedule communicated by regulator
column13: Examination Preparation: Pre-Examination Phase: upon examination notification, internal communication; identify examination coordinator; determine examination scope with examiner; identify relevant documents needed; organize documentation; schedule staff interviews; prepare conference room for examination. Documentation Organization: organize by control area (administrative safeguards, technical safeguards, physical safeguards, privacy rule, incident response, business continuity, vendor management, training, compliance); each control area includes: policy documentation, procedure documentation, testing results, evidence of implementation, findings and remediation. Create examination binders with tabs for each control; documentation in logical order; easy navigation for examiner. Specific Documentation Needed: information security program written policy; safeguard elements documentation; risk assessment documentation and updates; incident response plan; business continuity plan; disaster recovery plan; vendor agreements and assessments; vendor monitoring documentation; training documentation; testing and audit results; prior examination findings and remediation evidence; board minutes related to compliance; privacy notices; opt-out procedures. Staff Preparation: identification of relevant staff; interview schedule with examiner; interview preparation (understanding of documents, understanding of procedures, understanding of controls); designated spokesperson for each area; availability for interviews. Examiner Engagement: clarification of examination scope; information about institution changes; information about recent incidents; information about compliance efforts; open communication; responsiveness to requests. Examination Procedures: Initial Meeting: examiner explains examination objectives; outlines scope; outlines timeline; requests documentation; identifies key contacts; discusses ongoing examination schedule. Document Review: examiner reviews submitted documentation; clarifies procedures; identifies questions; requests additional information. On-Site Examination: examiner visits institution; reviews controls; interviews staff; tests systems; observed access controls; inspects facilities. Testing Procedures: control testing; compliance testing; risk assessment review; incident response procedure testing; business continuity testing; access control testing; encryption verification. Interview Process: staff interviewed on: understanding of GLBA requirements; understanding of institution's safeguards; understanding of incident reporting; understanding of confidentiality obligations; understanding of their role in compliance; assessment of compliance culture. Findings Identification: examiner identifies deficiencies; controls not adequately implemented; controls not effectively tested; gaps in compliance; areas for improvement. Finding Severity: Matters Requiring Attention (MRA): minor issues, no material compliance risk; Supervisory Letter or Report: more significant deficiencies; Matter of Concern: significant deficiency requiring specific remediation; Violation: clear violation of GLBA requirements; Enforcement Action: serious violation with possible penalties or orders. Remediation Planning: management meets with examiner to discuss findings; develops remediation plan with timelines; resource allocation; interim controls if necessary; progress reporting; management commitment. Formal Response: written response to examination findings; agreement or disagreement with findings; remediation plan including: specific actions; timeline; responsible parties; interim measures; progress reporting. Remediation Tracking: track remediation progress; implement remediation actions; verify effectiveness; progress reports to examiner; closure certification. Follow-Up Examination: examiner may follow up to verify remediation; testing of corrected controls; satisfaction with remediation; clearance of findings. Documentation of Examination: maintain examination file with: examination notice; examination scope; examiner communications; request lists and responses; examination findings; remediation plan; progress tracking; follow-up results. Post-Examination Assessment: identify trends in findings; areas for control improvement; process improvements based on examination; training adjustments; policy updates. Remediation Timelines: urgent findings (violations) require immediate remediation; 30 days common timeline; some actions require longer timeline; interim controls while permanent remediation implemented; documentation of progress. Regulatory Reporting: potential notification of remediation progress; may be formal or informal; documentation of communications; approval of remediation completion. Examination Outcomes: satisfactory compliance; satisfactory compliance with recommendations; compliance with remediation required; violation with enforcement action; multiple violations triggering enforcement. Repeat Findings: if issue found in multiple examinations; more serious; increased regulatory scrutiny; possible enforcement action; demonstrated commitment to remediation important; root cause analysis needed. Worst Practices: poor documentation; lack of responsiveness to examiner requests; inadequate remediation of prior findings; inadequate testing program; lack of board awareness of findings; inadequate resource commitment to remediation. Best Practices: proactive compliance focus; thorough testing program; documented remediation of issues; responsive to examination; transparent communication; board engagement; resource commitment to compliance; continuous improvement culture.

definition: Documentation system for GLBA compliance including policies
status: and examination materials. Documentation retained per policy and legal requirements for regulatory examination and potential enforcement proceedings.
key_features: Per GLBA Privacy Rule and Safeguards Rule, institutions must maintain documentation demonstrating compliance with GLBA requirements. Documentation serves multiple purposes: evidence of implementation; evidence of testing; evidence of management oversight; evidence of remediation; evidence of compliance culture. Documentation system components: centralized repository; organized by control area; version control; retention policy; access controls; secure storage. Retention: indefinite for certain documents; 2-3 years minimum for testing and audit results; 5 years for incident files; retention per regulatory requirements; longer retention for documents related to enforcement actions.
column11: All financial institutions; required for all institutions; applies to all control areas; applies to all safeguard elements; documentation maintained throughout compliance program
column12: Chief Compliance Officer for documentation system; Records Manager for retention and storage; IT for system security; Compliance staff for document management; Audit for testing documentation retention
column13: GLBA Safeguards Rule Section 314 documentation requirements; Privacy Rule documentation requirements; Federal Rules of Civil Procedure document retention; Regulatory examination expectations; State law retention requirements; Banking regulator guidance on documentation
column14: Mandatory requirement; documentation required for examination; documentation required for potential enforcement; inadequate documentation results in enforcement finding; documentation demonstrates control implementation
column15: Documentation System Components: Centralized Repository: single location for compliance documentation; physical and electronic storage; organized by control area; version-controlled; searchable; secure access. Documentation Categories: Administrative Policies: information security policy; privacy policy; incident response policy; business continuity policy; vendor management policy; training policy; personnel security policy. Procedures: detailed procedures for implementing each policy; step-by-step instructions; responsibility assignments; approval workflows. Test Plans and Results: annual audit plan; audit procedures; testing results; findings documentation; remediation tracking. Risk Assessment Documentation: risk assessment procedures; risk assessment results; risk inventory; control design documentation. Incident Documentation: incident logs; incident reports; forensic investigation results; regulatory notifications; breach notifications; remediation tracking. Vendor Documentation: vendor assessment results; vendor agreements; vendor monitoring records; audit reports; incident tracking. Training Documentation: training attendance records; training completion certifications; training materials; training effectiveness assessments. Board Materials: board resolutions; board meeting minutes; presentations to board on compliance; board approvals of policies and plans. Examination Materials: examination notices; examination requests; responses to requests; examination findings; remediation plans; correspondence with examiners. Compliance Certification: management certifications of compliance; officer attestations. Version Control: document versioning system; tracking of changes; effective dates; approval documentation; previous versions archived; clear identification of current version. Access Controls: restrict access to compliance documentation; limited to appropriate personnel; audit log of access; confidential treatment; secure storage prevents unauthorized access. Physical Storage: secure location (locked cabinet or secure room); fire-resistant safe for critical documents; environmental controls (temperature, humidity); inventory of stored documents. Electronic Storage: secure server or cloud storage; encryption of sensitive documents; backup and disaster recovery; access restrictions; password protection; multi-factor authentication for sensitive files. Specific Documents to Retain: Information Security Program (indefinite or per policy life): GLBA information security policy; annual reviews and updates; implementation procedures; board approvals. Risk Assessment (ongoing): initial risk assessment; annual updates; risk inventory; control design documentation; risk remediation; retain indefinite. Testing and Audit Results (3-5 years minimum): annual audit plan; audit procedures; test results; findings documentation; remediation tracking. Incident Logs and Reports (5+ years): incident log entries; incident reports; forensic investigation results; notification documentation; remediation documentation. Privacy Notices (indefinite): all versions of privacy notices; distribution records; opt-out documentation; consumer requests and responses. Vendor Files (3+ years): vendor assessment; contracts; monitoring records; audit reports; incident history; termination documentation. Employee Training Records (3 years): training attendance; training completion; training materials; training assessments. Board Materials (3-5 years): board resolutions on compliance; minutes of board meetings discussing GLBA; board approval of policies and plans. Examination Materials (retain indefinitely or per legal hold): examination notices; responses to examination requests; examination findings; remediation plans; correspondence. Compliance Certifications (indefinite): management certifications; officer attestations; authorized signatory records. Retention Policies: Define Retention Period: different retention periods for different document types; minimum retention (typically 2-3 years); longer retention for high-risk or enforcement-related; indefinite retention for policy and program documents. Disposal Procedures: secure destruction of physical documents; shredding or incineration; secure deletion of electronic documents; certificate of destruction obtained; no information recovery possible. Legal Hold: if litigation pending or enforcement action threatened; legal hold placed on relevant documents; documents retained indefinitely; no disposal without legal approval. Regulatory Requests: if regulator requests documents; document retention period extended; cooperation with request; timely production; confidentiality maintained if applicable. Examination Readiness: documents organized for easy examination access; examination binders prepared; able to produce any document within reasonable time; documentation demonstrates compliance. Documentation Standards: Consistency: standardized formats; consistent naming conventions; logical organization. Completeness: all required information included; supporting documentation included; clear relationships between documents. Currency: documents kept updated; version control maintained; obsolete documents clearly marked; current versions readily accessible. Security: access restricted; audit logs maintained; encryption of sensitive data; confidentiality protected. Quality: legible documents; clear writing; understandable procedures; professional presentation. Common Deficiencies: inadequate documentation; lack of version control; poor organization; inadequate retention; loss of documentation; inability to locate documents for examination; incomplete testing documentation; lack of audit trail.
